I'm trying to formalize https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/connected+space#basic, Example 3.4. They deal with

example {Œ± : Type*} {œÄ : Œ± ‚Üí Type*} [‚àÄ a, topological_space (œÄ a)] [‚àÄ a, connected_space (œÄ a)] (U‚ÇÅ U‚ÇÇ : set (Œ† a, œÄ a))
  (h‚ÇÅ : is_open U‚ÇÅ) (h‚ÇÇ : is_open U‚ÇÇ) (hne‚ÇÅ : U‚ÇÅ.nonempty) (hne‚ÇÇ : U‚ÇÇ.nonempty) (hd : disjoint U‚ÇÅ U‚ÇÇ)
  (hU : U‚ÇÅ ‚à™ U‚ÇÇ = univ) : false

I don't understand how they prove that one can choose x ‚àà U‚ÇÅ and y ‚àà U‚ÇÇ that differ only at a finite number of indices.

Observe first that if so, then we could find x1‚ààU1x_1\in U_1x1‚Äã‚ààU1‚Äã and x2‚ààU2x_2 \in U_2x2‚Äã‚ààU2‚Äã whose coordinates differed only at a finite subset of III. This is since by the nature of the Tychonoff topology œÄi(U1)=Xi\pi_i(U_1) = X_iœÄi‚Äã(U1‚Äã)=Xi‚Äã and œÄi(U2)=Xi\pi_i(U_2) = X_iœÄi‚Äã(U2‚Äã)=Xi‚Äã for all but a finite number of i‚ààIi \in Ii‚ààI.

What property of the Tychonoff topology do they use here? I interpreted their formulas as

example [‚àÄ a, topological_space (œÄ a)] {s : set (Œ† a, œÄ a)}
  (hs : is_open s) : ‚àÉ I : finset Œπ, ‚àÄ f g‚ÇÅ g‚ÇÇ, I.piecewise f g‚ÇÅ ‚àà s ‚Üî I.piecewise f g‚ÇÇ ‚àà s :=

but this doesn't seem to be true for s = ‚ãÉ a, {f : Œ† a, œÄ a | f a ‚àà t a}, where t a : set (œÄ a) is an open set.
@Yury G. Kudryashov we have docs#is_topological_basis_pi which could be helpful for this
So, the correct argument should say something like: take x1‚ààU1x_1\in U_1x1‚Äã‚ààU1‚Äã and x2‚ààU2x_2\in U_2x2‚Äã‚ààU2‚Äã. For each of them, take a nhd from the basis. Then proceed as in ncatlab.
I should've tried to think about it again in the morning before posting a question.
Well, I don't think you can choose x1,x2x_1,x_2x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã ahead of time. But you can show that for some x1x_1x1‚Äã and x2x_2x2‚Äã this property holds

The point is that UiU_iUi‚Äã contains a set of the form ‚àèiAi\prod_i A_i‚àèi‚ÄãAi‚Äã where for all iii, Ai‚äÇXiA_i \subset X_iAi‚Äã‚äÇXi‚Äã is open, and for all but finitely many of the iii, one has Ai=XiA_i = X_iAi‚Äã=Xi‚Äã.

@Yury G. Kudryashov in case it helps

import topology.bases

variables {Œ± : Type*} (X : Œ± ‚Üí Type*) [‚àÄ i, topological_space (X i)]

open topological_space

theorem foobar (x y' : Œ† i, X i) (U : set (Œ† i, X i))
  (hU : is_open U) (hy' : y' ‚àà U) :
  ‚àÉ (y : Œ† i, X i) (hy : y ‚àà U) (F : finset Œ±),
  ‚àÄ i, i ‚àâ F ‚Üí x i = y i :=
begin
  have Ti : ‚àÄ i, is_topological_basis { A : set (X i) | is_open A } :=
    Œª i, is_topological_basis_opens,
  have T := is_topological_basis_pi Ti,
  obtain ‚ü®V,‚ü®Vs,F,hV,rfl‚ü©,hV2,hV3‚ü© := T.exists_subset_of_mem_open hy' hU,
  classical,
  let y : Œ† i, X i := Œª i, if hi : i ‚àà F then y' i else x i,
  refine ‚ü®y,_,F,_‚ü©,
  { apply hV3, simp,
    intros i hi,
    dsimp [y],
    rw if_pos hi,
    simp at hV2,
    apply hV2 i hi },
  { intros i hi,
    dsimp [y],
    rw if_neg hi }
end
I'm sure you could golf it to 5 lines ;)

I modified docs@filter.mem_infi' to give a bit more info, then wrote

lemma exists_mem_eventually_eq_cofinite_of_mem_nhds [Œ† a, topological_space (œÄ a)]
  {s : set (Œ† a, œÄ a)} {x : Œ† a, œÄ a} (hs : s ‚àà ùìù x) (y : Œ† a, œÄ a) :
  ‚àÉ z ‚àà s, ‚àÄ·∂† a in cofinite, (z : _) a = y a :=
begin
  simp only [nhds_pi, mem_infi', mem_comap] at hs,
  rcases hs with ‚ü®I, hI, V, hV, hV_univ, rfl, -‚ü©,
  choose t ht htV using hV,
  refine ‚ü®I.piecewise x y, mem_bInter $ Œª i hi, _, mem_cofinite.2 (hI.subset _)‚ü©,
  { exact htV i (by simpa [hi] using (mem_of_mem_nhds (ht i))) },
  { exact compl_subset_comm.2 (Œª i, piecewise_eq_of_not_mem _ _ _) }
end

The new mem_infi':

lemma mem_infi' {Œπ} {s : Œπ ‚Üí filter Œ±} {U : set Œ±} : (U ‚àà ‚®Ö i, s i) ‚Üî
  ‚àÉ I : set Œπ, finite I ‚àß ‚àÉ V : Œπ ‚Üí set Œ±, (‚àÄ i, V i ‚àà s i) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ i ‚àâ I, V i = univ) ‚àß (U = ‚ãÇ i ‚àà I, V i) ‚àß U = ‚ãÇ i, V i :=
begin
  simp only [mem_infi, set_coe.forall', bInter_eq_Inter],
  refine ‚ü®_, Œª ‚ü®I, If, V, hVs, _, hVU, _‚ü©, ‚ü®I, If, Œª i, V i, Œª i, hVs i, hVU‚ü©‚ü©,
  rintro ‚ü®I, If, V, hV, rfl‚ü©,
  refine ‚ü®I, If, Œª i, if hi : i ‚àà I then V ‚ü®i, hi‚ü© else univ, Œª i, _, Œª i hi, _, _‚ü©,
  { split_ifs, exacts [hV _, univ_mem] },
  { exact dif_neg hi },
  { simp [Inter_dite, bInter_eq_Inter] }
end
Though I guess, it will work with the old mem_infi' as well.
That new mem_infi' can definitely replace the old one.
